subsection.title: Terminology
subsection.p: Just as there are arithmetic operations on numbers, there are set operations on sets.

statement.p: The set C is the union of the sets A and B, denoted A \cup B, if and only if C=\{ x | x \in A \mbox{ or } x \in B \}.
The set C is the intersection of the sets A and B, denoted A \cap B, if and only if C=\{ x | x \in A \mbox{ and } x \in B \}.
The set C is the difference between the sets A and B, denoted A-B, if and only if C=\{ x | x \in A \mbox{ but } x \not\in B \}.

subsection.p: In many circumstance there is a universal set that is part of the context for a problem. For example the set of all integers may be the universal set for discussion of even and odd numbers.

statement.p: The set C is the complement of the set A with respect to the universal set U, denoted \neg A or \overline{A}, if and only if C=U-A.
The set P is the power set of a set A, denoted \Pow(A) or 2^A, if and only if P is the set of all subsets of A.
The set C is the Cartesian product of the sets A and B, denoted A \times B, if and only if C=\{(a,b) | a \in A \mbox{ and } b \in B. \}.

subsection.p: For example if A=\{0,1\} and B=\{a,b\} then A \times B = \{(0,a), (0,b), (1,a), (1,b)\}.
